item.title: Color Everything in CSS
item.author: Juan Diego Rodr√≠guez
item.content:encoded: And I must admit: I didn‚Äôt know a lot about color in CSS (I still used¬†, which apparently isn‚Äôt what cool people do anymore), so it has been a fun learning experience. One of the things I noticed while trying to keep up with all this new information was how long the glossary of color goes, especially the¬†‚Äúcolor‚Äù¬†concepts. There are ‚Äúcolor spaces,‚Äù ‚Äúcolor models,‚Äù ‚Äúcolor gamuts,‚Äù and basically a ‚Äúcolor‚Äù something for everything.They are all somewhat related, and it can get confusing as you dig into using color in CSS, especially the new color functions that have been shipped lately, like and . Hence, I wanted to make the glossary I wish I had when I was hearing for the first time about each concept, and that anyone can check whenever they forget what a specific ‚Äúcolor‚Äù thing is.As a disclaimer, I am not trying to explain color, or specifically, color reproduction, in this post; that would probably be impossible for a mortal like me. Instead, I want to give you a big enough picture for some technicalities behind color in CSS, such that you feel confident using functions like¬†¬†or¬†¬†while also understanding what makes them special.Let‚Äôs slow down first. In order to understand¬†¬†in¬†, we first need to understand the¬†¬†in¬†.Light waves are out there in the world, but color happens in the interaction between light waves and the eye, brain, and mind.Even if color isn‚Äôt a physical thing, we still want to replicate it as reliably as possible, especially in the digital era. If we take a photo of a beautiful bouquet of lilies (like the one on my desk) and then display it on a screen, we expect to see the same colors in both the image and reality. However, ‚Äúreality‚Äù here is a misleading term since, once again, the¬†¬†of color depends on the viewer. To solve this, we need to understand how light wavelengths (something measurable and replicable) create different color responses in viewers (something not so measurable).Luckily, this task was already carried out 95 years ago by the International Commission on Illumination (CIE, by its French name). I wish I could get into the details of the experiment, but we haven‚Äôt gotten into our first color thingie yet. What‚Äôs important is that from these measurements, the CIE was able to map all the colors visible to the average human (in the experiment) to light wavelengths and describe them with only three values.This new color space also has three values, X and Z represent the chromaticity of a color, while Y represents its luminance. Since it has three axes, it makes a 3D shape, but if we slice it such that its luminance is the same, we get all the visible colors for a given luminance in a figure you have probably seen before.This is called the¬† diagram¬†and holds the colors visible by the average human eye (based on the average viewer in the CIE 1931 experiment). Colors inside the shape are considered real, while those outside are deemed imaginary.The purpose of the last explanation was to reach the CIEXYZ¬†Color Space¬†concept, but what exactly is a ‚Äúcolor space‚Äù? And why is the CIEXYZ¬†¬†so important?The CIEXYZ Color Space is a mapping from all the colors visible by the average human eye into a 3D coordinate system, so we only need three values to define a color. Then, a¬†color space can be thought of as a general mapping of color, with no need to include every visible color, and it is usually defined through three values as well.The most well-known color spaces are the RGB color spaces (note the plural). As you may guess from the name, here we only need the amount of red, green, and blue to describe a color. And to describe an RGB color space, we only need to define its ‚Äúreddest‚Äù, ‚Äúgreenest‚Äù, and ‚Äúbluest‚Äù values. If we use coordinates going from 0 to 1 to define a color in the RGB color space, then:¬†means the reddest color.¬†means the greenest color.¬†means the bluest color.However, ‚Äúreddest‚Äù, ‚Äúbluest‚Äù, and ‚Äúgreenest‚Äù are only arbitrary descriptions of color. What makes a color the ‚Äúbluest‚Äù is up to each person. For example, which of the following colors do you think is the bluest?As you can guess, something like ‚Äúbluest‚Äù is an appalling description. Luckily, we just have to look back at the CIEXYZ color space ‚Äî it‚Äôs pretty useful! Here, we can define what we consider the reddest, greenest, and bluest colors just as coordinates inside the xy chromaticity diagram. That‚Äôs all it takes to create an RGB color space, and why there are so many!In CSS, the most used color space is the standard RGB (sRGB) color space, which, as you can see in the last image, leaves a lot of colors out. However, in CSS, we can use modern RGB color spaces with a lot more colors through the¬†¬†function, such as¬†,¬†, and¬†.Notice how the ProPhoto RGB color space goes out of the visible color. This is okay. Colors outside are clamped; they aren‚Äôt new or invisible colors.In CSS, besides sRGB, we have two more color spaces: the CIELAB color space and the Oklab color space. Luckily, once we understood what the CIEXYZ color space is, then these two should be simpler to understand. Let‚Äôs dig into that next.CIELAB and Oklab Color SpacesAs we saw before, the sRGB color space lacks many of the colors visible by the average human eye. And as modern screens got better at displaying more colors, CSS needed to adopt newer color spaces to fully take advantage of those newer displays. That wasn‚Äôt the only problem with sRGB ‚Äî it also lacks perceptual uniformity, meaning that changes in the color‚Äôs chromaticity also change its perceived lightness. Check, for example, this¬†demo by Adam Argyle:Created in 1976 by the CIE, CIELAB, derived from CIEXYZ, also encompasses all the colors visible by the human eye. It works with three coordinates: L¬†for perceptual lightness, a¬†for the amount of red-green, and b* for the amount of yellow-blue in the color.It has a way better perceptual uniformity than sRGB, but it still isn‚Äôt completely uniform, especially in gradients involving blue. For example, in the following white-to-blue gradient, CIELAB shifts towards purple.As a final improvement,¬†Bj√∂rn Ottosson¬†came up with the Oklab color space, which also holds all colors visible by the human eye while keeping a better perceptual uniformity. Oklab also uses the three¬†¬†coordinates. Thanks to all these improvements, it is the color space I try to use the most lately.When I was learning about these concepts, my biggest challenge after understanding color spaces was not getting them confused with color models and color gamuts. These two concepts, while complementary and closely related to color spaces, aren‚Äôt the same, so they are a common pitfall when learning about color.A refers to the mathematical description of color through tuples of numbers, usually involving three numbers, but these values don‚Äôt give us an exact color until we pair them with a color space. For example, you know that in the RGB color model, we define color through three values: red, green, and blue. However, it isn‚Äôt until we match it to an RGB color space (e.g., sRGB with¬†display-p3) that we have a color. In this sense, a color space can have several color models, like sRGB, which uses RGB, HSL, and HWB. At the same time, a color model can be used in several color spaces.I found plenty of articles and tutorials where ‚Äúcolor spaces‚Äù and ‚Äúcolor models‚Äù were used interchangeably. And some places were they had a different definition of color spaces and models than the one provided here. For example, Chrome‚Äôs¬†High definition CSS color guide¬†defines CSS‚Äôs RGB and HSL as different color spaces, while MDN‚Äôs¬†Color Space entry¬†does define RGB and HSL as part of the sRGB color space.Personally, in CSS, I find it easier to understand the idea of RGB, HSL and HWB as different models to access the sRGB color space.A is more straightforward to explain. You may have noticed how we have talked about a color space having more colors than another, but it would be more correct to say it has¬†a ‚Äúwider‚Äù gamut, since a color gamut is the¬†range of colors available in a color space. However, a color gamut isn‚Äôt only restricted by color space boundaries, but also by physical limitations. For example, an older screen may decrease the color gamut since it isn‚Äôt able to display each color available in a given color space. In this case where a color can‚Äôt be represented (due to physical limitation or being outside the color space itself), it‚Äôs said to be ‚Äúout of gamut‚Äù.In CSS, the only color space available used to be sRGB. Nowadays, we can work with a lot of modern color spaces through their respective color functions. As a quick reference, each of the color spaces in CSS uses the following functions:¬†We can work in sRGB using the ol‚Äô hexadecimal notation, named colors, and the¬†,¬†,¬†,¬†¬†and¬†¬†functions.¬†Here we have the¬†¬†for Cartesian coordinates and¬†¬†for polar coordinates.¬†Similar to CIELAB, we have¬†¬†for Cartesian coordinates and¬†¬†for polar coordinates.More through the¬†¬†and¬†.¬†Outside these three color spaces, we can use many more using the¬†¬†and¬†¬†functions. Specifically, we can use the RGB color spaces:¬†,¬†,¬†,¬†,¬†¬†and the XYZ color space:¬†,¬†, or¬†. are a mapping between available colors and a coordinate system. In CSS, we have three main color spaces: sRGB, CIELAB, and Oklab, but many more are accessible through the¬†¬†function. define color with tuples of numbers, but they don‚Äôt give us information about the actual color until we pair them with a color space. For example, the RGB model doesn‚Äôt mean anything until we assign it an RGB color space.Most of the time, we want to talk about how many colors a color space holds, so we use the term for the task. However, a color gamut is also tied to the physical limitations of a camera/display. A color may be out-of-gamut, meaning it can‚Äôt be represented in a given color space.In CSS, we can access all these color spaces through color functions, of which there are many.The is extremely useful to define other color spaces, describe their gamuts, and convert between them. Light is the main cause of color, but color can be created by things other than light. For example, rubbing your closed eyes mechanically stimulates your retina, creating color in what‚Äôs¬†called phosphene. ‚§¥Ô∏è If ¬†also makes you scratch your head, and for more info on how the CIEXYZ color space was created, I highly recommend Douglas A. Kerr¬†The CIE XYZ and xyY Color Spaces¬†paper. ‚§¥Ô∏è¬†We also need to define the darkest dark color (‚Äúblack‚Äù) and the lightest light color (‚Äúwhite‚Äù). However, for¬†well-behaved¬†color spaces, these two can be abstracted from the reddest, blues, and greenest colors. ‚§¥Ô∏è

item.title: How to Keep Up With New CSS Features
item.author: Sacha Greif
item.content:encoded: How do you keep up with new CSS features?Let‚Äôs say for example that, hypothetically speaking, you run a popular web development survey focused on CSS, and need to figure out what to include in this year‚Äôs edition. (In a¬†¬†coincidence the aforementioned State of CSS survey for this year is actually open right now ‚Äî¬†go take it to see what‚Äôs new in CSS!)You might think you can just type ‚Äúnew CSS features 2025‚Äù in Google and be done with it. But while this does give us a few promising leads, it also unearths a lot of cookie-cutter content that proclaims CSS Grid as the ‚Äúnext big thing‚Äù, despite the fact it‚Äôs been well-supported for over eight years now.¬†We need a better approach.¬†I‚Äôll focus on CSS in this article, but all the resources linked here cover all web platform features, including JavaScript and HTML.The browsers themselves are often a good source of what‚Äôs new and, thankfully, the big ones maintain blogs where they even cover specific CSS news.A good general starting point is Google‚Äôs¬†web.dev¬†blog, and more specifically¬†Rachel Andrew‚Äòs monthly web platform recaps. Here‚Äôs a small sample of those:I‚Äôd be remiss to not mention that CSS-Tricks¬†is also a great source for up-to-date CSS knowledge, including an ever-growing almanac of CSS features. But you probably already know that since you‚Äôre reading this.And let‚Äôs not discount other fine publications that cover CSS. Here are just a few:Following individual sources can get a little overwhelming, particularly when CSS is moving as fast as it is. That‚Äôs where Frontend Dogma comes in with an ever-growing and updated list of curated links from these (and many other sources) in a one-stop shop.Another very cool feature is the ability to view a feature‚Äôs adoption rate, as measured in terms of percentage of Chrome page views where that feature was used, such as here for the¬†¬†HTML attribute:An important caveat: since sites like Facebook and Google account for a very large percentage of all measured page views, this metric can become skewed once one of these platforms adopts a new feature.The Web Platform Status‚Äôs¬†stats¬†section also features the ‚Äúchart of shame‚Äù (according to¬†Lea Verou), which highlights how certain browsers might be slightly lagging behind their peers in terms of new feature adoption.That same adoption data can also be found on the¬†Chrome Platform Status dashboard, which gives you even more details, such as usage among top sites, as well as sample URLs of sites that are using a feature.¬†Polypane Experimental Chromium Features DashboardKevin Powell‚Äôs YouTube ChannelOf course, you can always also go straight to the source and look at what the¬†CSS Working Group itself¬†has been working on! They have a mailing list you can subscribe to keep tabs on things straight from your inbox, as well as an RSS feed.Most browsers publish a set of release notes any time a new version ships. For the most part, you can get a good pulse on when new CSS features are released by following the three big names in browsers:Another way to catch up with CSS is to just ask¬†ChatGPT! This sample prompt worked well enough for me:What are the latest CSS features that have either become supported by browsers in the past year, or will soon become supported?¬†If you really want to get in the weeds, Igalia‚Äôs BCD Watch displays changes to MDN‚Äôs¬†browser-compat-data repo, which itself tracks which features are supported in which browsers.¬†Also, the latest editions of the HTTP Archive Web Almanac do not seem to include a CSS section specifically, but¬†past editions did feature one, which was a great way to catch up with CSS once a year.¬†There‚Äôs also¬†caniuse¬†has a¬†news section¬†which does not seem to be frequently updated at the moment, but could potentially become a great resource for up-to-date new feature info in the future.And lastly, there‚Äôs a ton of folks on social media who are frequently discussing new CSS features and sharing their own thoughts and experiments with them. If you‚Äôre on Bluesky, there‚Äôs a starter pack of CSS-Tricks authors that‚Äôs a good spot to find a deep community of people.Of course, another great way to make sure no new features are slipping through the cracks is to take the State of CSS survey once a year. I use all the resources mentioned above to try and make sure each survey includes every new important feature. What‚Äôs more, you can bookmark features by adding them to your ‚Äúreading list‚Äù as you take the survey to get a nice recap at the end.So go take this year‚Äôs¬†State of CSS¬†survey and then let me know on¬†Bluesky¬†how many new features you learned about!
